issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.summary: In getNumUnderConstructionBlocks(), ignore the inodeIds for which the inodes have been deleted

comments.body: [~yzhangal] Maybe you can add some debug info for null inode id that could help to trace what ids have null inode and eventually trace back what caused it.

Hi [~yzhangal] thanks for the patch.

I think it makes sense to add a safeguard to the code as you pointed out. It is reasonable for me to not add a test associated with since it's a safeguard.

To help find out the bug, which we still don't know where it originates, could you add a warning message when the inode is null? +1 after that.

 

As a side note, it looks like there are a number of places in the code where we delete leasesById, but we don't delete the corresponding inode in inodeMap. FSNamesystem#removeLeasesAndINodes() does it, but not all places where leases is deleted invoke this method.

For example, FSDirSnapshotOp#deleteSnapshot() calls FSDirectory#removeFromInodeMap() but it doesn't seem to remove from inodeMap.

Thanks for the review [~billyean] and [~jojochuang].

I had the message earlier but somehow dropped. I will add it back.

Uploaded new rev, found I was using HADOOP instead of HDFS in previous rev, so I removed it.

Thanks.
